Award.AwardTitle: Instructional Sequences in Pre-College Engineering Education

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This engineering research project will examine the cognitive aspects of instructional designs for pre-college students who are novices in engineering. A set of rigorous empirical experiments will investigate instructional sequences that dynamically adapt engineering representations, practice, and feedback as pre-college students advance from novices to competent problem solvers in a basic engineering knowledge domain.

The research team will use mixed quantitative and qualitative methods within a set of randomized controlled experimental studies with pre-college students in outreach programs. This project will reach over 1,000 pre-college students, including a large portion of minority students, who will participate in the proposed experiments in Arizona. The project participation has the potential to significantly promote the pre-college students? engineering problem solving skills, as well as self-efficacy and interest in engineering. In addition, the findings of this project will inform the development and implementation of effective outreach programs nationwide, thus substantially increasing their effectiveness to attract underrepresented groups to engineering careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit Impact

The project research has contributed to the fundamental understanding of effective representation of engineering concepts and problems for pre-college engineering learning as well as effective feedback strategies for engineering learning. Three experimental studies demonstrated the effectiveness of abstract representations employing the standard abstract engineering symbols for the first engineering learning experiences of novice learners. Presently, introductory engineering learning materials for novices are typically highly contextualized, emphasizing the real-life contexts of the engineering concepts. The representation sequencing studies conducted in this project indicated that a different strategy that first teaches the underlying engineering concepts in an abstract setting and then moves on to instantiations of the concepts in real-life contexts leads to more effective learning. Moreover, engineering instructional materials are presently predominantly printed or displayed in black (or one uniform color). The color coding (representation) research conducted in this project indicated that printing or displaying the variables for the different engineering quantities consistently in different font colors can aid novice learners.

A study conducted on the effects of representations in hands-on circuit activities has contributed to the understanding of the effects of engineering outreach activities on the range of K-12 students. Results for elementary school students indicated that the stereotypical perceptions of engineering had not yet permeated the young females. This result together with the findings that elementary school students derived higher enjoyment for the circuit kit activity despite experiencing higher cognitive load than the high school students underscore the importance and potential of electrical circuit outreach at the elementary school level. Thus, this project research has contributed further empirical evidence that preconceived notions of engineering develop over K-12 education and support early outreach interventions to help avoid the formation of negative attributions to engineering by minority (e.g., female) students.

The feedback sequencing study conducted in this project pioneered the study of feedback sequencing (transitioning) in instruction on problem solving in engineering, and generally in STEM knowledge domains. Feedback provided throughout an instructional session after each problem step (also known as immediate feedback) as well as feedback provided throughout an instructional session after a complete problem attempt (also known as delayed feedback) have been studied extensively in the feedback literature. However, feedback sequencing (transition), i.e., the increase or reduction of feedback frequency had previously been mainly investigated for training of human motor skills. Also, a few studies had examined feedback sequencing in the context of military training for missions and in organizational management. The feedback sequencing study conducted as part of this project was the first to examine this attractive instructional design strategy for the domain of problem solving instruction in STEM disciplines. Thus, the feedback sequencing study provided critical baseline assessment results and insights that can serve as a basis for follow-up studies and novel practical instructional designs.

 

Broader Impact

The project has increased the awareness of engineering among the middle and high school teachers who have helped organize the module presentations in the schools.
